results.description:
Update; December 1st:


Hi Everyone,  Only 3 out of 12 spots remaining!   Book now to reserve your spot for our adventurous & relaxing wintertime getaway!  :)

Initial post:

Our winter getaway takes us to the Caribbean to visit the colorful, tropical island of Puerto Rico! Puerto Rico is a volcanic island, and part of the Greater Antilles located in the north-central Caribbean between the Virgin Islands and the Dominican Republic.

The main island of Puerto Rico is only approximately 100 miles long by 35 miles wide, and offers diverse terrestrial and marine ecosystems including coastal mangrove forests, seagrass beds, coral reefs, tropical rain forests, tropical dry forests, and coastal plains!

For our trip we have chosen to escape the bustling, eastern side of Puerto Rico and head to the quieter ‘wild western’ coastal region. The super laid-back surf village of Rincón will be our home away from home!

Rincón is referred to as Pueblo del Surfing (the surfing town) and El Pueblo de lost Bellos Atardeceres (the town of beautiful sunsets)!   Not to worry, you do not have to be a surfer to enjoy all that it has to offer!

Rincón is considered a natural and authentic seaside paradise, where emerald hills meet intimate, golden beaches. Rincón is located on a point of land which jets west to a point and meets the Caribbean and Atlantic Oceans, and offers several distinct and intimate beaches. Each day you get to choose the beach which fits your preferred water activities!

One of the coolest qualities of Rincón is that the separation between tourists and locals is more seamless than other resort-type towns. Aside from the beautiful beaches, the best part will be socializing with the warm, open, friendly and fun locals!  In fact the locals will be tour guides, showing us the best spots to find relaxation, fun, food, or tropical beverages with fantastic views! We will have a great time utilizing the local entrepreneurs to enrich our trip and experiences!

Rincón became known as one of the world’s top surfing destination in 1968 when the World Surfing Championship was held at Rincon’s own Domes and Maria’s beaches. Generally regarded as one of the best surf spots across the globe, Rincón draws surfers from around the world and is the center of the island’s surf scene. Dubbed the “Caribbean’s Hawaii, or the Hawaii of the Atlantic ” winter waves here can approach 25–30 feet (6.7m) in height, sometimes equaling the force of the surf on Oahu’s north shore!

Rincón is also emerging as a Yoga retreat destination as it offers Yogi-tourists the opportunity to practice on the beach and at open-air studios. Yogi’s can even opt to challenge their practice by participating in group classes on the water with SUP yoga, in the air with Aerial yoga or combine a class with a hike in the hills.

During our trip to Rincón we have planned just enough activities and adventures with a good amount of free time for relaxing or exploring on your own. March is the perfect time to escape winter… and no better place to break free from hibernation than Rincón, Puerto Rico! Whether you prefer calm waters for swimming or waters with awesome surf breaks, Rincón has it all! And, should you tire of beaches you can hop in a car and be up in tropical mountains within minutes! In Rincón you get to choose your own adventure, eat and drink in laid back Caribbean places, and even explore a quaint 240 year old town!

About our accommodations:

We have reserved one of the best rental villas in Rincon!  Our villa is large and private AND it is right on the beach!  It is two stories with 6 bedrooms, 5 bathrooms, two kitchens, two living rooms/dining rooms, a thatched palm gazebo, swimming pool and large deck on bluff overlooking the beach!  There will be more than enough room for 12 of us to spread out and enjoy beautiful outdoor places to relax with the gang and enjoy! 


Another HUGE bonus is our home is within walking distance to several little shops and restaurants!  A short walk down the beach is Tamboo; which is one of Rincon's hangouts right on the beach and features live latin music!  

This trip is for both DC & Baltimore Gen-Xers (only 12 people total!).  Our trip is for 5 nights (4 full days); Wednesday, March 9th - Monday, March 14th.


Go here to see all the great details and to reserve your spot!   Reserving your spot means filling out a brief booking form and paying a 30% deposit.  Once you do, please message me for preferred room assignment!
results.name: SOLD OUT - Winter getaway to Puerto Rico!

results.description:
Annapolis has a lot of great places to meet for happy hour during the week. It's a good reason to get out of the house and an easy way to try a variety of different restaurants and pubs in town. An added attraction is that happy hour menus at most places make the drinks and food more affordable. 

Ruth's Chris Steakhouse has an upscale ambience and prices to match at its location on Severn Avenue in Eastport. However, they have a selection of affordable happy hour special dishes and drinks before 6:30 pm that should make this a nice classy outing for our group. Parking is available on neighborhood streets if you don't use the valet parking.  Happy hour details below:

http://www.ruthschris-annapolis.com/Sizzle-Swizzle-Swirl.htm

Special happy hour menus and prices are typically only available in the bar area, so that's where we'll meet to enjoy a good time. As a general rule, our SHR group prefers gathering in the bar area where we can freely mingle and get separate checks with no hassles about group ordering. We also receive much better service by ordering and paying directly at the bar.


I plan to arrive by 5:00 pm to find a good spot in the bar area. I hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the bar area

results.description:
Register and Pay Now  Leading for Performance -  Hunter Haines

According to recent research by the Gallup organization, the level of employee engagement in the United States in 2015 was 32 percent. Gallup defines engaged employees as those that are involved in, enthusiastic about, and committed to their work and workplace.

Unfortunately, that means that 68 percent of workers in organizations in the United States are disengaged.  If some of these disengaged employees work for you, it’s highly unlikely you’re getting their best performance.  Join us on March 9 to learn the ways to engage your employees and drive business results.

Hunter Haines, MS, CPLP, ACC, ODCP is an Organization Development and Inclusion Consultant at the University of Maryland Medical System.  In this role, Hunter helps leaders develop skills to maximize employee and team performance.  Hunter is also an ICF-certified coach and consultant and the owner of People Leading People.

results.description:
Set in and around Eisen, this game is a sandbox-styled game using the 7th Sea system. All of the D10 source material is open for use with the following caveats/modifications. 

Pregens will be available for you to play if you like. 
Rerolling is freely allowed(keeping earned xp) for the first three games. 
A standard 100pts is available at char creation. Any randomized choices will be rolled at the table. 
You may reroll any randomized chargen choice(arcana, etc) at a cumulative cost of 1xp per reroll. 
Spent drama dice will ALSO convert into xp(total drama dice xp capped at maximum number of drama dice) if used for doing something in a flashier or more dramatic manner than necessary.
Sidhe and part-sidhe characters are banned. If you've played before, you know why. 
Characters may not begin as full members of any secret society. If one is selected, they are acolytes at char creation. Note that secret society advantage purchasing will be allowed after char creation as a result. 
We are playing the D10 version of the system. 

The rules compendium is freely available here: http://www.alderac.com/7thsea/resources/7thsea_compendium.pdf

I will bring additional rulebooks to game for use during the session.
results.name: 7th Sea Open Game

What this course is about: We will be holding an 10-week Introduction to Insight Meditation course starting Wednesday January 13. The classes will run each Wednesday from 6:15 to 7:15 p.m. (note: No class on 2/3) Each class stands alone, so it is acceptable to attend one class or all of them (though it is helpful to attend as many as possible, since there is some overlap).

Each class will include: guided meditation (15 minutes), instruction, opportunities to practice, and time for discussion, questions and answers.

These classes are designed to teach beginners the basics of mindfulness, meditation and Buddhist philosophy.

2/24 Concentration and Open Awareness

results.description:
Wednesday, March 9, 6:30 p.m.

The Charm City Film series presents I AM DIVINE: The True Story of the Most Beautiful Woman in the World.

I AM DIVINE is a definitive biographical portrait of Harris Glenn Milstead, a.k.a. Divine, and honors him in just the way he always craved — as a serious artist and immortal star. Divine’s entire story is told, from his early days as a misfit youth in Baltimore through his rise to infamy as a cult superstar.

As outrageous and fun as its subject, I AM DIVINE combines movie clips, rare home movies and photos, television appearances and live performance footage with brand new interviews with John Waters, Ricki Lake, Mink Stole, Tab Hunter, Holly Woodlawn, Michael Musto, Bruce Vilanch, mother Frances Milstead, and many of Divine’s family, friends, colleagues, and devotees.

The film is free and open to the public. Donations are suggested. Refreshments are provided, and films are followed by discussion led by a local expert on the issue.

For more information on the Baltimore ethical society:

Website: baltimoreethicalsociety.org

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/bmorethical

Phone:[masked]

The Met stage ignites when soprano Kristine Opolais and tenor Jonas Kaufmann join forces in Puccini’s obsessive love story. 

Opolais sings the title role of the country girl who transforms herself into a Parisian temptress, while Kaufmann is the dashing student who desperately woos her. Director Richard Eyre places the action in occupied France in a film noir setting. 

“Desperate passion” is the phrase Puccini himself used to describe the opera that confirmed his position as the preeminent Italian opera composer of his day. Met Principal Conductor Fabio Luisi leads the stirring score.

results.description:
Under raging storm clouds, the vampire Count Strahd von Zarovich stands silhouetted against the ancient walls of Castle Ravenloft. Rumbling thunder pounds the castle spires. The wind’s howling increases as he turns his gaze down toward the village of Barovia. Far below, yet not beyond his keen eyesight, a party of adventurers has just entered his domain. Strahd’s face forms the barest hint of a smile as his dark plan unfolds. He knew they were coming, and he knows why they came; all according to his plan. A lightning flash rips through the darkness, but Strahd is gone. Only the howling of the wind fills the midnight air. The master of Castle Ravenloft is having guests for dinner—and you are invited.

This is the launch event for the next D&D Storyline, The Curse of Strahd. New players are always welcome and pre-generated characters will be provided if needed. Levels of play are from 1-4.

results.description:
If we're too loud to sit by the Scrabble Club, then we're doing something right!

Our March book, inspired by tales shared at our January meeting of wild South Pacific islands and rides in tiny planes, is Headhunters on My Doorstep: A True Treasure Island Ghost Story by J. Maarten Troost.


We had a fantastic turnout for the January meet, including several new faces and plenty of fantastic stories. I may never fall asleep on a plane again! Thanks to all who came. By the March meeting, Caitlin will be back from India with new tales (and snack tips). I hope to see even more of you then!

From Amazon.com: Follow in the footsteps of Robert Louis Stevenson with J. Maarten Troost, the bestselling author of The Sex Lives of Cannibals.

Readers and critics alike adore J. Maarten Troost for his signature wry and witty take on the adventure memoir. 

Headhunters on My Doorstep chronicles Troost’s return to the South Pacific after his struggle with alcoholism left him numb to life. Deciding to retrace the path once traveled by the author of Treasure Island, Troost follows Robert Louis Stevenson to the Marquesas, the Tuamotus, Tahiti, Kiribati, and Samoa, tumbling from one comic misadventure to another. 

Headhunters on My Doorstep is a funny yet poignant account of one man’s journey to find himself that will captivate travel writing aficionados, Robert Louis Stevenson fans, and anyone who has ever lost his way.

The book is available in every format, with multiple copies in the AA County Public Library. Amazon has used copies for $5.92 (including shipping).

As always, donations are accepted online or at meetings, all toward the $15/month Meetup charges to host our group. Much appreciation to those who've kicked in a few bucks!

Happy New Year to everyone, and I hope you'll join us soon.

results.description:
The focus of this topic is intended to be on the pairing of dominance and acquiescence and the transactions in which this interaction takes place, especially among individuals and their groups. It was originally thought this narrow view was just a construction of my own, but a brief review of the literature showed some scholarly attention to these very aspects.

The two main sources used to construct what follows are Anatomy of Power ( JK Galbraith, 1983) and Power: The Inner Experience (DC McClelland, 1973). The first book addressed the many aspects of power including types, sources, instruments, regulation, and dialectic. On this last point, Galbraith suggests that there is rampant discussion on power with little attention to what it really is and how it is actually used, often illustrated by the rush to accuse of exploitation and conspiracy.  M. Foucault also has expressed dissatisfaction about the prevalent negative discourse on power. He sees power is primarily a matter of administration of life and should be addressed as a system of power relations. He offers that it has positive productive effect serving as a source of creativity and innovation. 

On defining power, Galbraith and others are in concurrence that power is a state and not an action, and it is only the possibility of employing force to impose one’s will on another. He extensively treats dominance and acquiescence as the two sides of a transaction where power is translated into force. 


The McClelland book is psychological in nature and is an extensive review of research work in the motives for acquiring power. Much of the analyses are structured around the Freudian ego development model as tempered by Erikson. I say “tempered” as Erikson takes a less dark view of man as an inherently violent being and allows for more caring, altruistic, and empathetic dealings in collective situations. The stages are: 

   A.  Stage I – “It” strengthens me – nurturing 
   B.  Stage II – I strengthen myself - willfulness or assertion of self 
   C.  Stage III – I have impact on others – controlling others 
   D.  Stage IV – It moves me to do my duty – dictated by higher authority 


Galbraith proceeds to identify three types of power: 
   A.  Type 1 – Condign (punishment/pain) –physical pain, deny action, rebuke, withholding 
   B.  Type 2 - Compensatory (affirmative reward) – something of value, wage/salary/ bonus, praise 
   C.  Type 3 – Conditioning (changing beliefs) - charisma/vision/social commitment, education, media/”big data”, position, prestige 

Galbraith’s sources of power: 
   A. Personality – physical presence (tall, good-looking, charming, affable, sincere, trustworthy, confident, capable, eloquent, leadership; able to assert the unknown with conviction (exaggeration); connect to values 
   B. Property – possessions of value; barter chips; capability extenders 
   C. Organization – internal solidarity seeking outside submission 
      1. Diversity of participants and clients 
      2. Number and diversity of purposes - strength is inversely related to the diversity 
      3. Conciseness, comprehensiveness, and consistency of internal rules 
      4. Range and emphasis of power options used 
      5. Symmetry of internal and external strategies 


Dialectic of Power – how to achieve its dissolution 
   A. Negotiation – ask for better terms 
   B. Resistance/refusal; revolution 
   C. Building a countering position of power; enlist a third party/protector; regulator; boycott 


Free will and determinism once again raise questions since acquiescence clearly can open the door for choice. The absolute determinists should find that the research into motivations for power suggests a fundamental role of fantasy (man’s highest aspirations and greatest reward) in constructing ones’s view of power derived either from within or from others.
results.name: Power, Dominance, and Acquiescence – Transactions, Perceptions, and Instruments

results.description:
What: This is an open ongoing mindfulness meditation group for both beginners and experienced practitioners.

While the forms of meditation we practice are rooted in Buddhist teachings, the study and practice of mindfulness and insight meditation is applicable to anyone from any background or religion, and all are welcome.

These teachings are available to all. Although a $10 donation is suggested, donations are not required for attendance.


Each class will include: guided meditation, instruction, opportunities to practice, and time for discussion, questions and answers.

When and where: We meet every Wednesday from 7:30-9:00 p.m. at Centennial High School, 4300 Centennial Lane, Ellicott City, MD, 21042, room 406. Please arrive early to settle into your seats - we start right at 7:30 p.m. [Note: Class will be canceled on days that the school is closed.]

We practice Insight Meditation, a style of meditation that helps the mind attain deeper levels of calm concentration through sustained attention on the breath, then combines this with the crucial aspect of insight through contemplation of the mind and body and all of their changing and impermanent senses, emotions and thoughts. Insight Meditation trains us to live more fully in the present moment, enables us to experience life from a greater stillness, and aids us in relating to both ourselves and others with increased clarity, compassion, calmness and creativity, and less fear, anxiety and stress.

Along with these and a long list of other psychological benefits, meditation has also been shown to reduce stress hormones in the body, lower blood pressure, reduce anxiety, alleviate depression and boost the immune system.

Teacher:

Stan Eisenstein, a high school physics teacher who has been meditating for 25 years and has been practicing Insight Meditation since 2004. Stan is a mentor with the Insight Meditation Community of Washington (IMCW) and is a graduate of the Meditation Teacher Training Institute, a two-year certification program with senior Insight teachers Tara Brach, Jonathan Foust, Hugh Byrne, and Pat Coffey. He also teaches Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction (MBSR) and Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT). Stan also earned a Masters of Social Work in 1998.

Centennial High School Parking (see map below) - September through June:

If coming to the school from the South (Route 108) side of Centennial Lane, make a left into the bus loop just as you reach the school. Immediately on your left is a drive to a parking lot on the south/left side of the school. Park in this lot and follow the signs to room 406.

If coming to the school from the North (Route 40) side of Centennial Lane, make a right into the bus loop just as you finish passing the school. Immediately on your left is a drive to a parking lot on the south/left side of the school. Park in this lot and follow the signs to room 406.

Suggestions:

1. There are plenty of chairs, but if you prefer to sit on the floor, which is carpeted, please bring a hard pillow or zafu, since, when meditating, it is recommended that your hips be higher than your knees. If you have never tried sitting on the floor during meditation, it is highly recommended that you try the chair first, then practice sitting on the floor at home until you are comfortable.

2. If you have any back issues, please bring a pillow or cushion to place behind you.

3. The chairs are hard, so you may wish to bring a cushion with you to sit on.

4. Please remember to turn off your cell phones before entering the room.

5. Please try not to wear any perfume to the sit, as it can be quite distracting to others. Also, with respect to those who may be allergic, we do not use incense.

6. The group is not recommended for those under age 13.

Please feel free to contact Stan Eisenstein at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
Park at the Lakeview Office Park parking lot on the other side of Brokenland Parkway from the dam end of Lake Elkhorn, Columbia, MD, 21046.  Please read the whole description below:


• Please go to the LAKEVIEW Office Park at 9821 Broken Land Parkway, Columbia, MD 21046.   Go to the driveway in front of the buildings and turn left.  Park by the edge of the woods.  Please take your dog out of the car, and look for people with dogs.  They will be looking for you & your dog too :)


•  If you are coming from Broken Land Parkway at the Columbia Mall direction, it is easier to turn into the Woodmere Office Park, at  9891 Broken Land Parkway, because it's at a traffic light, and you just turn right to get into it.  If you turn in here, drive toward the metal sculpture, and TURN LEFT.  Stay on this driveway, go through a stop sign, and continue driving, passing by all of the buildings on your right.  Keep driving all the way to the end, til you can't drive any further, and park at the edge of the WOODS.

• When you get out of the car, you should be able to see Lake Elkhorn from the parking lot.  The trailhead starts here at the edge of the woods, close to Broken Land Parkway.  This is where we will meet.  Please take your dog out and show him around so others will know they're in the right spot :) There is a tunnel that leads under Broken Land Parkway so we won't have to walk the dogs through traffic.  (The parking lot at the main entrance of the lake is too small to accomodate us, so we don't use the main entrance to the lake.)


• Please allow yourself time to arrive a few minutes BEFORE  the walk begins to allow the dogs to sniff each other and form their pack.  We will step off on time. We will turn right (counterclockwise) at the lake, so if you are late, and can run to catch us, turn right.  (Otherwise, if you're really late, turn left so you will run into us at some point and we can all walk together.)  If you cannot make it please change your RSVP in a timely manner, or leave a note in the comments section.  Thanks you.


• Six foot length fixed leashes are required for your dog.  Retractable leashes are dangerous and can amputate dogs' paws if they become entwined in them, so let's keep the dogs' safety at heart.  Thank you.


• If we stay over to the RIGHT we can avoid the runners and bikers.  Also, if you see a BIKE or a RUNNER coming towards us from either direction, please yell out "BIKE!" or "RUNNER!" or "ON YOUR LEFT!" so we can get our dogs safely to the RIGHT side to avoid them.  Everyone else please echo the warning so the whole group hears it. (Especially important for dogs who like to leap toward runners or bikers.)  Thank you. 


• Please bring water for your dog.  We will take water stops and photo ops and have fun with the pups :)


Please read all the points below:

Columbia Dogs on the Go provides a way for friendly people with FRIENDLY DOGS (please, no snarling, growling, lunging or snapping dogs) to meet people with similar interests on a voluntary basis. By replying "Yes" to this RSVP and attending this event, you acknowledge that:

•  You are responsible for your own safety and the safety of your dogs and any guests. 

•  Your dogs are current on their vaccinations.

•  Your dogs will be kept on a leash (Fixed Length, non-retractable) and under your control at the Meetup.

•  You will clean up after your dogs at the Meetup.

•  You will update your RSVP if your plans change.

•  You understand that the Meetup ends when the walk ends. (If you choose to meet other members at a restaurant, dog park, or other location, it is on your own time and not part of the Meetup event.)

Looking forward to seeing you and your doggies there!


                                                                                      Photos by J. Ameen-Lee

results.description:
An Encore Presentation by Popular Demand: 

Learn the exact marketing system of leading Silicon Valley apps to supercharge your mobile growth presented by Silicon Valley Mobile Growth Guru - Nagi Salloum 

TO REGISTER FOR THIS EVENT CLICK HERE

VIP:

We must limit the amount of registrants to 500, so sign up now. This event will sell out fast.

About the webinar:

Without a well engineered mobile-centric marketing system in place, like 90% of startups, you will most likely struggle to build consistent traction to grow your app before you run out of money (and consequently kill your startup).

In this webinar, you'll learn the exact marketing system of leading Silicon Valley apps, and real-world examples that will help you grow your app even if you don't have a marketing team or a marketing budget.

Some of what you'll learn:

• The 6 signs your marketing is killing your startup (without you knowing) and how to fix them.

• The critical 4 stages of marketing you need to master.

• A simple free hack to 40x your installs.

• How to hack Whatsapp to earn free installs

• How to hack the app stores to 5x your organic installs and a lot more.... 

About Nagi: 

Nagi has 12 years of marketing expertise and currently the founder of the Mobile Growth Academy, an online platform that offers mobile startups a step by step guide to help them market and grow their apps. 

Prior to that, Nagi was the head of global product marketing for Tango Messenger, a Silicon Valley company that raised over $350M and has 400M users worldwide. Nagi also served as the Chief Marketing Officer at N2V, a leading internet investment group, a regional marketing executive for Google, and as a regional brand manager for P&G . 

Nagi is also a board member, mentor and advisor to dozens of tech startups in Silicon Valley, Norway, Spain, Portugal, Mexico, UAE, UK, Germany, Egypt, Lebanon and many more..

Register Here Today - Later will be too late!
results.name: 4 Critical Steps To Explode Your Growth Like Silicon Valley's Top Mobile App

results.description:
A Pathfinder Society scenario for 1st to 5th level characters.

The Society’s excavations continue, now taking the PCs to the long-contested territory of Kharijite—Cheliax’s southernmost territory, where the great Arch of Aroden bridges the Hespereth Strait and establishes an Avistani foothold in Rahadoum’s backyard. There, an ancient Taldan ruin suggests that empire’s great Armies of Exploration traveled even farther than believed possible. Can the PCs uncover the site’s secrets—and in doing so reshape the Inner Sea region’s history?

“Lost Colony of Taldor” is the second scenario in the three-part Faithless and Forgotten campaign arc. It is preceded by Pathfinder Society Scenario #7–14: “Let Bygones Be” and followed by Pathfinder Society Scenarios #7–18: “The Infernal Inheritance.” All three chapters are intended to be played in order.

results.description:
Drinking Skeptically is an informal social event designed to promote fellowship and networking among skeptics, critical-thinkers, and like-minded individuals. Drinking Skeptically provides an opportunity for skeptics to talk, share ideas (and yes, drink) in a casual, relaxed atmosphere. We discuss the issues of the day and whatever else is on our minds. But most of all, we have fun while promoting skepticism, science, and rationality. Don't drink? Don't let that stop you from joining us! Some of the world's most famous skeptics are teetotallers, and we are happy to have you! Remember that drinking skeptically means drinking responsibly. If there's one thing science has taught us, it's the effects of alcohol on the human body. To learn more about Drinking Skeptically see www.drinkingskeptically.org

The area set aside be the establishment for our group is not wheelchair accessible. The venue has no age restriction for the duration of our event.

CFI-DC encourages people with disabilities to participate in its programs and activities. If you anticipate needing accommodations or have questions about physical access you may email sdavis [at] centerforinquiry [dot] net in advance of the event.
results.name: CFI–DC Drinking Skeptically Baltimore Meetup

results.description:
Greetings.

Spring is near and we would love to have you join us for a couple hours of breath.


This is a great way to experience the breath in a way  you may not have had before.  It is a great tool to relax, help manage stress and "dial back" some of those tension based responses.


No prior experience needed.  Men and women welcome.  If there is no specific theme emerging in the group then you can work on your own goals or we will create a topic on site.  First timers and returning faces always welcome.


Each evening goes like this:

1. Introductions

2. How things are going / breath instruction.

3. Breath experience

4. Sharing after the experience

Date: March[masked]


Time: 6.30pm - 8.30pm

Location: just South of Towson University

(exact directions will be sent to members coming to the meetup)

No prior experience is needed, just bring a willingness to try and an open mind.

Please arrive just before 630pm so that we can start on time and end right at 830pm.

You may want to bring a pillow with you.  Nothing special to wear, just something comfortable.

The $20.00 fee is payable at the door with cash or check.

If you have any questions, please contact me.

Look forward to seeing you there!

Peace

David

results.description:
Composition - Controlling the Eye's Journey

The presentation is about composition from the perspective of controlling the eye's journey around the photograph.  It will cover the use of 'thirds' as a guideline for position the primary objects in the image, including example images that show good thirds alignment. The value of curves and triangles as aids to composition will also be covered. Mike will also discuss the use of cropping to improve composition, and the impact of paper size and shape for printed images.  Mike will conclude with a couple of images that 'break' the rules successfully.
results.name: Howard County Photographers

results.description:
The novel begins in Monte Carlo, where our heroine is swept off her feet by the dashing widower Maxim de Winter and his sudden proposal of marriage. Orphaned and working as a lady's maid, she can barely believe her luck. It is only when they arrive at his massive country estate that she realizes how large a shadow his late wife will cast over their lives - resenting her with a lingering evil that threatens to destroy their marriage from beyond the grave.

First published in 1938, this classic gothic novel is such a compelling tale that it won the Anthony Award for Best Novel of the Century.

results.description:
The 5 Part Eating Psychology Introduction is a FREE workshop designed to guide you through your own personal exploration of your Relationship with Food. This workshop is inspirational for anyone looking to gain weight, lose weight, maintain their weight, or who deal with the demons or strengths of body perception. This workshop is ideal for anyone who is struggling with balancing lifestyle choices with meals and having a career. This workshop is suited for heads of households and the grocery shopper. This workshop will help people who eat at restaurants but prefer to be in their kitchens. This workshop is designed to lift the stigma of diet and how it affects you. 

This class is a blend of lecture and personal work, of group conversation and relative exploration through case studies discussions. “Homework” exercises will be assigned. 

Materials recommended for this class include a fresh journal or notebook, and your favorite writing implements.

This class series will begin on Thursday January 14th at 7:30pm and meet once monthly for 5 classes. Classes are held at 8232 Philadelphia Road in Rosedale, MD 21237. For more information Please call[masked], or email Lisa at [masked]. To learn more about Lisa Please visit <a>www.LK-CEPC.com.</a> 

CLASS 3 In this class you will begin a more profound and deeper exploration of your Personal Relationship with Food.

results.description:
WELCOME TO PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS CLUB

The mission of the Patuxent Toastmasters Club is to provide a supportive and positive learning experience in which members are empowered to develop communication and leadership skills, resulting in greater self-confidence and personal growth. 

Read below about the History of Toasting

Toastmasters International has awarded PATUXENT TOASTMASTERS with the SELECT DISTINGUISHED CLUB AWARD for club excellence in 2014/2015.

Patuxent Toastmasters is proud to introduce Jill LaVeck as the new club president for 2015 - 2016. Patuxent Toastmasters Humor and Evaluation Contest will take place on September 24th at 7:30.  All are welcome.

Congratulations to Phil Shaw who placed 1st in our first annual TALL TALES SPEECH CONTEST

Phil is being presented with the Tall Tales trophy after presenting a highly entertaining speech about winning the Masters Golf Tournament accompanied by the President.

Holiday Social 2014 Photos

Join us at Meetup.com http://www.meetup.com/patuxent-toastmasters/

Patuxent Toastmasters Club meets on the 2nd and 4th Thursdays of the month, upstairs at the historic Oliver's Carriage House in downtown Columbia.

We suggest that you arrive at 7:15 PM for some socializing; our meetings begin promptly at 7:30 PM and end at approximately 9 PM.  

MAP

All are welcome.  Our club offers a friendly, supportive, and diverse learning environment.  We have members from many different walks of life, ages, ethnicities, religions, and nationalities. Although we meet in a community church, our club has no religious affiliations.

Are you looking for speaking tips....go to toastmasters international 

https://www.toastmasters.org/Resources/Public-Speaking-Tips

Member Experience [img alt="Member Experience" border="0" class="headlineImage" data-cke-saved-src="http://www.toastmasters.org/OtherImages/MemberExperienceImage.aspx" src="http://www.toastmasters.org/OtherImages/MemberExperienceImage.aspx" title="Member Experience">

Being a member of Toastmasters International involves more than just showing up at meetings and giving a speech now and then.

Toastmasters membership is about being part of a supportive group of individuals in your local area who share the common goal of improving their communication and leadership skills.

From meeting roles and mentoring to speech contests and satellite programs, Toastmasters International offers a host of ways for members to progress and thrive.

Whether you’re a beginner or a long-standing member, the resources listed to the left will help make the most of the Toastmasters program.

Holiday 2012 Club photo

THE HISTORY OF TOASTINGAncient tradition is full of colorful tidbits. Every day around the world, cultures celebrate, honor and signify meaningful events with toasts, usually involving a libation, heartfelt words and the clinking of glasses. Whether toasting the Almighty, the head of state, the wedding party or an award recipient, we toast for health, wealth, happiness, safe passage, healing or any of a number of noble and sometimes frivolous aspirations.

Yet few people know the history behind this ritual. It’s a tradition that began centuries ago. “The ancient Hebrews, Persians and Egyptians were toasters, as were the Saxons, Huns and other tribes,” Paul Dickson writes in his book Toasts: Over 1,500 of the Best Toasts, Sentiments, Blessings and Graces.

In his 18th-century history book The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire, Edward Gibbons wrote about toasting, Dickson notes. Gibbons described a feast among the Huns at which their leader, Attila, led no less than three rounds of toasts for each course of an elaborate dinner.

Ancient Greeks drank to each other’s health and welfare. In The Odyssey, Ulysses drank to the health of Achilles. The idea of poison—which was a potent weapon in the sixth century B.C.—also came into play. According to David Fulmer’s book A Gentleman’s Guide to Toasting, toasting was “a good faith gesture to assure the drink wasn’t spiked with poison.” The best way to prove a drink was safe for sipping was to take the first sip. Just as a handshake assured others that nothing was hidden up one’s sleeve, drinking a shared libation in front of others signified to all its worthiness for consumption.

The Romans built upon this Greek custom of drinking to others’ health and well-being: They added toasted bread crumbs to their goblets, reducing the acidity of the often bitter wine. Thus came the appellation “to toast”— referring to the drink itself—from the Latin term “tostus,” meaning “to dry up" or "scorch." In Rome, "drinking to another’s health became so important, the Senate decreed that all diners must drink to Augustus [the first Roman emperor] at every meal,” Dickson writes. “Fabius Maximus [the Roman politician and general] declared that no man should eat or drink before he had prayed for [Maximus] and drank to his health.”

The Clinking of Glasses
The toasting custom spread throughout Europe and England, where for the first time the clinking of glasses accompanied the ritual. Whether its intent was to mix the content of each other’s glasses so everyone drank the same grog (lessening the likelihood of being poisoned), or to add sound to the experience of taste, touch, smell and sight, no one is sure.

In the 17th century, toasting became very popular, says Dickson. Eventually, the position of “toastmaster” emerged. In England, the toastmaster presided over events, delivering and soliciting appropriate toasts. “In those days the duties of the toastmaster tended to be referee-like in that his main function was to give all toasters a fair chance to make their contribution,” writes Dickson in his book.

He adds that one of the earliest books on toasting—if not the earliest—was The Royal Toastmaster by J. Roach, published in London in 1791. Roach’s view was that the toast is a very powerful ritual. Consider this passage from his book:

A Toast or Sentiment very frequently excites good humor, and revives languid conversation; often does it, when properly applied, cool the heat of resentment, and blunt the edge of animosity. A well-applied Toast is acknowledged, universally, to soothe the flame of acrimony, when season and reason oft used their efforts to no purpose.

To this day, one can find the National Association of Toastmasters in the United Kingdom—whose trained members wear ceremonial red dinner jackets and are skilled at oratory, poetry and toasting. They emcee events of all varieties, from weddings and funerals to christenings and fundraisers.

Dickson describes a Golden Age of toasting in America during the 40-year period from approximately 1880 to 1920. Many prominent authors wrote toasts, toast books and pamphlets were published, and newspapers ran columns on the subject. One periodical, The National Magazine, had its own Toasts editor, whose duties included judging the best toasts in a monthly contest, Dickson says.

Traveling Toasts
Worldwide, numerous nations and cultures have their own toasting customs. Many are similar to each other yet others are unique. For example, in Japan, China and Korea, the customary toasts sound very similar but are pronounced differently. According to the Matador Network (www.matadornetwork.com), a site devoted to travel journalism, toasters in Japan say the word kanpai and pronounce it “kan-pie”; in China they say gan bei and pronounce it “gan bay”; in Korea they say gonbae and pronounce it “gun bae.”

And Korean toasting customs differ from the Japanese. “In Korea, the glass is emptied and the last few drops are shaken out, then it is passed to the guest and the host refills the glass,” says the website Etiquette International (www.etiquetteinternational.com). “A glass is never refilled until it is completely empty in Korea, whereas in Japan the glass is constantly refilled so it is never empty.”

If you’re going to make a toast in another country, notes the site, be sure to find out the toasting customs there “before putting your foot in your mouth.” “Toasts don’t necessarily translate well, especially if they are idiomatic or poetic,” adds Etiquette International. “It’s a good idea to stick to safe topics like friendship, the enjoyment of life and health.”

The ancient and international tradition of toasting is no doubt one that will endure for many more years. Let’s hope the future of the toast is as engrossing as its past.

results.description:
This week Single Again Crofton a guest speaker will be speaking on the topic "Feelings:  Then & Now".  How did we feel when we first separated?  What has happened to those feelings over time?  Am I still just putting one foot in front of the other, and living on "auto pilot"?  Do I continue to blame others or have I come to terms with my part in the events that have happened?  Do I continue to throw myself into activities (work, the children, binge drinking/eating/etc.) to avoid dealing with my new "normal" or have I started to move forward into reshaping my new life?  These are all questions that each of us is dealing with every day.  Come to Single Again tomorrow evening and share your thoughts and ideas on how feelings are shaping you into the new person whom you are becoming.   

Orientation Meeting begins at 7:00 PM for new members

Regular Meeting begins at 7:30 PM

Then there will be small-group break-out sessions.

results.description:
LESS MATH, MORE WRATH!

Step through the portal into a labyrinthine dungeon filled with mystical chambers, ravenous monsters, and nefarious tricks sprawled endlessly across crumpled sheets of graph paper. The Tower of Gygax is a classic dungeon crawl as envisioned by E. Gary Gygax. It is a game of wonder and danger whose currency is imagination and improvisation!

The Tower of Gygax is an eleven-story spiraling behemoth, its rooms and inhabitants drawn from the many worlds of D&D. In each session, the dungeoneers must make their way through one of the lairs occupying a level of the Tower; solving puzzles, battling monsters, and avoiding traps in an effort to escape with treasure and trophies in hand. The way through the Tower is uncertain and perilous.

Foolish or unlucky dungeoneers will meet a quick demise.

Guarding the exit of each floor is a dreaded Dungeon Lord - a fearsome villain whose defeat heralds a fountain of unholy might that can be used by the dungeoneers to increase their own power, Highlander-style. The final, eleventh floor contains the lair of the most dreaded Dungeon Lord and gatekeeper of the Tower - the demilich Acererack!

The Tower of Gygax takes pride in its fast, fierce, deadly, and entertaining gameplay. Since its inception at GenCon, the Tower has earned a reputation as being a terrifying, must-attend event. Now, Dungeon Master Ross has brought forth this gem of gaming goodness right to your front door!

Players can expect all materials, including PreGen character sheets, to be provided. Players who are new or inexperienced with the game rules are heartily welcomed.


Timid players with cautious or apathetic playstyles need not apply.

results.description:
Give your toddler to preschooler (18 months to 4 years) sensory experiences to optimize their musical, physical, language, social, emotional and cognitive development.  Children explore and react to new sounds, sensations, and environments. They use developmentally appropriate instruments like shakers, bells, drums, and tambourines in instrument-play activities that engage and develop both hemispheres of the brain. They benefit from both side-by-side play with other children, and engaging interactions with you.  In class we'll sing, listen, play, and dance together–all key ingredients in your child’s development of social skills.

Children will develop both gross- and-fine motor skills through fingerplays and movement activities. They’ll discover more about how their bodies work as they explore movement activities through steady beat, dynamics, tempo changes, patterns and stop & go play.   

It’s never too early to give your child a musical start. Come join the fun and experience the delight of watching your child learn and grow in Kindermusik classes.

Contact Peggy Durbin to visit a FREE class for 18 months to 4 years of age with adults.

results.description:
When: March 11, 2016, Autumn 2016, Spring 2017


Time: 6-8PM

Where: Mitchell Gallery - St. John’s College, Annapolis, MD

Cost: $50 Single/ $75 Family

Payment: At signup

Description: Join other Crabtowne art and wine lovers for wine, hors d’oeuvres, and the opening of a new exhibition at the Mitchell Gallery. If you have never visited this little gem at St. John’s College, now is the time. Only Gallery members are invited to these delightful special opening receptions, and with your participation in this event, you will be given a Gallery membership good until June of 2017, during which time, there will be two additional opening receptions in autumn 2016 and spring 2017.  This  exhibition is entitled:

American Impressionism: The Lure of the Artists’ Colony

This comprehensive exhibition features 50 oil paintings and nearly 20 works on paper dating from the 1880s through the 1940s. Outstanding landscapes—ranging from snow covered hills to sun filled harbors—seascapes, penetrating portraits, and remarkable still lifes, imbued with rich textures, reveal the artists’ interest in capturing effects of light and atmosphere in their work.

Arranged according to the artists’ colonies that played a critical role in the development of American Impressionism, including those at Cos Cob and Old Lyme in Connecticut; Cape Cod, Cape Ann, and Rockport, in Massachusetts; New Hope and Philadelphia in Pennsylvania; Taos, New Mexico; and California. American expatriate artists such as Mary Cassatt and John Singer Sargent are examined as well as leading artists of the movement: William Merritt Chase, Childe Hassam, Ernest Lawson, Julian Alden Weir, John Twachtman, Chauncey Ryder, Frank W. Benson, William Paxton, Abbott Thayer, Guy Wiggins, Charles Webster Hawthorne, Colin Campbell Cooper, Daniel Garber, and Edward Redfield, among others.

Drop dead date: March 8, 2016

Directions: Rt. 50 onto Rowe Blvd. Left at Calvert St. light.  Left onto St. John’s Street.  Parking lot is on the right (uplifted gate).  To enter Gallery, walk away from St. John’s Street lot entrance toward the grassy area and follow the side of the Mellon building to the third entrance on the right at Mitchell Gallery.  Map provided at signup.

results.description:
After a lot of searching we picked out some of the best educational and inspirational short videos for this Meetup (as usual).  In keeping with this month's theme of weight loss, here’s what we'll show you on Friday:  

Renowned health authority and health communicator, Dr. Neal Barnard, in a 9-minute video summarizing the most important weight loss principles. 

A 9-minute video from the great Dr. Michael Klaper on restaurant eating, and olive oil. 

A 15-minute video by Dr. Garth Davis, a bariatric specialist, on his clear and direct approach to educating patients, which is contrary to many unsuccessful conventional approaches. 

A 12-minute dynamic presentation about ‘slaying dragons’ by the inimitable Rip Esselstyn

(If we want even more, we've picked out a couple of  3-minute shorts from the great Dr. Michael Gregor of NutritionFacts.org on the essential principle of Calorie Density).    

But we want to leave plenty of time for discussion, as well. 

One of us will bring a giant bowl of delicious food that is probably the key to weight loss and good health.  If everyone could eat a large portion of this simple, delicious food every day, which we all keep in our kitchens, we believe that success is guaranteed.

We'll talk about the important concept of “salad” - but not just any salad.  A conventional "salad" may seem unappealing.   However, the trick is to learn to make salads that you *love,*  with a lot of variety and delicious extras, along with an OIL-FREE dressing that you also *love.*   This is a key principle for weight loss and health. 

On Friday you'll learn to make a variety of Amazing Salads which are bone fide Super Foods: the more you eat,  the more weight you lose!  

Others will have their own suggestions on favorite oil-free dressings and fixings. 

But man, and woman, does not live on salad alone.  Comfort foods are critically important for satiation and satisfaction! Think potatoes.  Also brown rice, corn, other whole grains, beans dishes, etc., etc., etc.  These are unprocessed starchy foods.  (Did you know that 90% of the carbohydrates Americans eat are processed??)  A good rule of thumb, according to our friend Chef A.J., is to have the salad or veggies “before the good stuff,”  i.e. before the healthy, satisfying carbohydrates. 

Your four organizers, Joe, Vlad, Emily and Jamila, will be on hand to help and advise you during and after this meeting. Vlad and Jamila are experienced, knowledgeable and inspiring.  Joe is an M.D. and Emily is an R.D. (Registered Dietician).  We're not looking for paying clients.  In fact, Joe and Emily don't accept paying clients.  We just want to help, as volunteers. 

Please bring a dish that is vegan (no dairy, egg, fish or meat of any kind), and not too much, if any, SOS (salt, oil, sugar).

It's not mandatory to bring food, but please try to bring something to share that fits these criteria, so that we don't run short.  It's a pot luck.  You can get some ideas at <a>www.NutritionAsMedicine.org.</a>   If no time to cook, you can just bring some fruit, etc.  If you're new to all of this, or if you're not in a position to bring anything for some reason, that's OK, just bring yourself (and friends).  

And if you're new to all of this, you're especially welcome.

If you are bringing a dish, PLEASE bring a piece of paper with your name, the name of the dish AND INGREDIENTS (or recipe, even better, but at least ingredients - for those who are food-sensitive or following certain diets).  Your name, and name of the dish, is so people can ask you for the recipe.

If anyone has questions or wants to chat, please call Joe Adams M.D. at[masked] if you're not sure this is right for you, or if you're looking for a little help on how to break out of whatever barriers you might be facing.

Please join the free, twice-monthly conference calls for extra support and information, with some of the organizers and other participants.  They’re always on the Third Thursday and First Tuesday of each month, at 7:30 pm.  The next calls are Thursday March 17th at 7:30 pm, and Tuesday April 5th at 7:30 pm.  The dial-in number is always:[masked], and the access code is always[masked]#.   These calls are listed as ‘Upcoming Meetups’ - Please RSVP (optional) in the Upcoming Meetups section:  http://www.meetup.com/Baltimore-Nutrition-As-Medicine-Potluck/?scroll=true

There’s also a buddy system where anyone can keep in touch and help each other, and one-on-one support provided by the volunteer organizers. 

We can't wait to see you there!

-   Joe, Vlad, Emily and Jamila, the Nutrition As Medicine team.
results.name: Let's talk about WEIGHT LOSS (while we eat!)

results.description:
Jews and chocolate first met in 1492, when Spanish royals Isabella and Ferdinand signed the Alhambra Decree and the Jews were forced to leave the kingdom of Spain.  Displaced Jews established flourishing communities in the areas of the Caribbean and Central and South America that were under Dutch and English control.  After cultivating positive relationships with native peoples who taught them how to process cacao and extract vanilla from beans, Jews began exporting the new products to factories in Europe.  This multisensory history program is hosted by award-winning cookbook author Sheilah Kaufman.  Come prepared to eat chocolate and enjoy happy hour drinks.

$15 for members and pre-event purchases; $20 at the door.

results.name: History Happy Hour: The Bittersweet History of Jews and Chocolate

results.description:
… Naturally is the theme at the library for Spring 2016 and we will be exploring the natural world through exhibitions and programs, including the annual Juried Photography Exhibition. Weather… Naturally! will open at the Jarrettsville Library during National Library Week with an opening reception on Sunday April 10th. The show will run through June 1st. Professional and amateur regional photographers are invited to submit one (1) photograph to be considered for inclusion. Work can be black and white or color; vertical or horizontal; any size up to 11” x 14”; you may NOT manipulate your photos by computer or hand except for cropping and minor corrections. They should be “natural.” Please closely consider the theme of the show. We are looking for fine art photographs inspired by, created by, or depicting the weather – good, bad, blustery, and beautiful. Photos must relate to weather in some way.

Twenty-four entries will be blindly selected for the show by a committee including the Library Community Relations Specialist, a local photographer not submitting, and a representative of the Harford County Cultural Arts Board. Notification of inclusion will be to the email address used to submit photos and will take place on or before March 18, 2016.

Once selected for inclusion, photographs must be framed at the artists’ cost in the Studio Décor® Basics Metro Frame (available locally and online at Michael’s - http://www.michaels.com)

The 24 works hanging in the show will be blindly judged by a panel of three the day of the reception. The judges will include two professional photographers who have not submitted. Prizes will be $250 for 1st; $150 for 2nd; $100 for 3rd; 2 Honorable Mentions of $50.

To be considered for the exhibition, email one submission photo (no smaller than 400x400px and no larger than 600x600px) to Bethany Hacker, [masked], by March 11, 2015.

Photos may be picked up at the close of the show, after June 6, 2016. Those not picked up by June 20, 2016 become the property of the Library.

results.description:
Time: 

8 a. m.: at the Severna Park Park & Ride at I97 Exit 10 - Severna Park (Benfield Blvd. & Veterans Highway) behind the Exxon Station and next to Severna Park Racquetball Club. 

9 a.m. at the trail head.

Hiking should be over around the noon time frame.

Where: 

8 a.m.: Meet at the Park & Ride; I-97 Exit 10 - Severna Park (Benfield Blvd. & Veterans Highway); behind the Exxon Station and next to Severna Park Racquetball Club. 

9 a.m.: Meet at the trail head. 

Cost: No cost. Pay as you go if we decide to meet for lunch after the hike.

Description: The trailhead begins at the Visitor Center. There are 7 miles of marked trails which to choose upon. Soldiers Delight Natural Environment Area (NEA) is comprised of 1,900 acres of serpentine barren. The area has over 39 rare, threatened, or endangered plant species as well as rare insects, rocks and minerals. Rare grassland plant species are threatened by invasion of Virginia Pines. Currently, a five year effort of removing 1,000 acres of pines and prescribed burning are underway to return the area to natural serpentine habitat. Difficulty: easy-to-moderate.

Directions: If you miss your connection at the Park & Ride. Follow I-97 N, I-695 W and I-795 N/Northwest Expressway to Franklin Blvd in Reisterstown. Take exit 7B from I-795 N/Northwest Expressway. Take exit 7B for Franklin Blvd. West, right at Church Road, left on Berrymans Lane, then left on Deer Park Road. The address is 5100 Deer Park Road, Owings Mills, MD. 21117.

Cancellation: Standard Club Policy - Unless Otherwise Noted

Leader: Christine Hunt,
Email; [masked]

results.description:
The Maryland Food Bank needs an accurate estimate of how many people will be volunteering for this event, so please update your RSVP as soon as possible if you aren't able to make it to this event.

=======================================


IMPORTANT VOLUNTEER INFO:

Open-toe shoes are PROHIBITED at the warehouse.  Wear clothes that you don't mind getting dirty (which probably won't happen, but it's a possibility).

Please arrive to the warehouse ON TIME.  We can't begin until EVERYONE is at the warehouse.

Additional volunteer info can be found at the MD Food Bank's website, at www.mdfoodbank.org.


=======================================

The Maryland Food Bank was founded in 1979 to coordinate the procurement and distribution of food donations from manufacturers, wholesalers, retailers and government agencies to organizations providing free food to the state's hungry.

Volunteers usually work on a high-tech conveyor belt in the warehouse, pulling specific types of food from the belt as they pass, and packing the sorted food into 25 - 50-pound boxes. Full boxes are then placed on the Maryland Food Bank's daily menu, available for more than 600 soup kitchens, pantries and shelters across the state to order.

results.description:
I highly recommend this to the folks who have been coming for the Saturday meditations. A nice Hatha yoga session compliments your morning meditation very well. This set of graceful yoga asanas (postures) helps prepare the body and mind for deeper meditation. One of the key tips is to stay relaxed throughout the practice. Benefits include: helps with weight loss, picks up metabolism, raises overall awareness and intuition, calms the mind.

This Yoga session will include:
* Pranayama breathing
* 2 repetitions of 15 posture Hatha Yoga
* Yoga Nidra (lying down)

This is open for beginners. Please bring a Yoga mat, a towel and bottle of water.

If you have any medical concerns or complications please let me know before the class begins. This is a donation based Yoga session, suggested donation $5.

results.name: Community Hatha Yoga

We'll join up with the Baltimore Tree Trust to plant trees in Ellwood Park. These are bare root trees, so nice and light. And, trees do wonderful things for water, air and neighborhoods! Come join us in making a difference. :)

Baltimore Tree Trust will lead the volunteer effort starting at 9 am with a short 'how to plant trees' demonstration. Tools, gloves, location maps are provided and trees will already be set out for planting. Dress for outdoor work and bring your own water bottle.

Meet at the park which is located at the intersection of Jefferson St and N Potomac St.
results.name: Plant trees in Ellwood Park

venue.name: Kitchen and Fellowship Hall at New Life Mennonite  Church

results.description:
A potluck BREAKFAST?   Sure, something different.   

I love breakfast, I love having breakfast with friends, conversation over coffee, eggs and pancakes, and of course bacon!

This is kinda an idea-in-progress......I'd like to do it every other month or so and we will learn what works and what doesn't work.  

Cost $3.00, this covers the stuff I will bring such as paper products and utensils, coffee and tea bags and the fixings (sugar, cream, etc.), butter and syrup, jelly, other condiments. 

Plus...you bring a carton or two of eggs, or a package of bacon/sausage, fruit, bread, milk, orange juice, danish, coffee cake or other sweets, etc.   You could make-ahead and bring breakfast potatoes or hash browns to make in the oven when you arrive.  We'll need vegetables cut up to put in omelettes.  And a box of the 'complete' pancake mix where you just have to add water.  

We will COOK breakfast for ourselves and for one another.   I will have three electric griddles, so we can make pancakes and French toast.  I even have a waffle maker that I can bring.    And aprons....and cooking tools, etc.  

The church has a full kitchen with refrigerator, residential-type stove and microwave.

This will be very informal, very relaxed time to enjoy making and eating breakfast together while socializing and enjoying one another's company. 

I have friends at this church and the space is generously being donated for our group to use.  We don't have to pay for using the facility, we just need to leave it as clean as we found it, so I will need some clean-up help after the breakfast.  I am very thankful for the use of their facility.  

Again, if this goes well, I hope to do this meetup several more times in 2016.  We'll learn what works best and how to do a potluck breakfast.
results.how_to_find_us: Park in the Lot or along the street, enter the church through the red doors, go downstairs to the basement
results.name: Potluck Breakfast, 9:00 AM

results.description:
One of the more scenic routes in the Patapsco Valley State Park in the Hilton Area which includes multiple stream crossings, cascade waterfalls, two swinging bridge crossings, Ilchester Overlook, and Bloedes Dam. This is a moderate hike and can be hiked in either direction. Counterclockwise is an easier hike with lesser inclines. Clockwise has more inclines, some rocky terrain and about 1200′ of cumulative ascent. While beginning in the Hilton Area, this hike includes the Avalon, Orange Grove and Glen Artney areas of PVSP.

EveryTrail.com - Review of Hike

results.description:
Full details can be found by following this link. 

The Permaculture Design Certificate (PDC) course is a training program that utilizes the teachings of Bill Mollison’s Permaculture Design System. The goal is to achieve a basic working understanding in ecologically-based planning, site design and management. This course provides a comprehensive introduction to Permaculture principles, applications & design practices as first set out by Permaculture founder, Bill Mollison.

Key skills and proficiencies learned include: surveying, communications, IT and web skills, preparing maps and plans, practical gardening, composting, soil management, animal systems, natural building, implementation planning, design graphics, client brief, concept and detail drawings, report writing, botany, propagation, food forests and orchards, native plants, integrated pest and weed management, planning food security, small crop production – vegetables, herbs, spices, craft plants, harvest and post harvest, storing and preserving crops, wild foods and restoration ecology, soil food web, seed saving and managing a seed bank, biochar, animal systems, and more.

Prerequisites: None
The PDC includes the standard 72-hour international PDC curriculum, addressing all major climatic zones (temperate, subtropic, tropical & arid) and the breadth of Permaculture applications for sustainable urban, suburban, rural, and bioregional design and development.
Course length: 72+ hours over 12 days
Course Dates: March 12, 13, 26 & 27 April 9, 10, 23 & 24 May 14, 15, 28 & 29
Meals: Assigned “Potluck”
Daily Schedule: 10am – 4pm
Instructors: Eric Kelly
Early Bird: $520 runs until November 30th
Second Mid Early Bird: $620 runs until January 31st
Regular Course Fee: $720
Maximum Attendants: 20
Two work trades are available, but will not be decided until end of February. Email to inquire.
Location: Baltimore, MD 21202 & 21213 Plus one field trip day

PDC Suggested Preparatory Reading: You will be emailed the Permaculture Institutes PDC course outline
Introduction to Permaculture, Bill Mollison
Gaia’s Garden, Toby Hemenway

Course Topics:
Permaculture principles
Concepts and themes in design
The local ecosystem
Forms of eco-gardening and farming
Broad scale site design
Design drafting using Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop
Pattern understanding
Climatic factors
Plants and trees and their energy interactions
Water, soils, earth-working and earth resources
Zone and sector analysis
Food forests
Small animal husbandry
Harvest and natural forests
Aquaculture
Planning the homestead
Structures
Renewable energy and energy conservation
Waste management and recycling
Permaculture strategies for different climates
Urban and suburban Permaculture
Small farm and garden management and marketing
Strategies of an alternative global nation
Practical work on design
results.name: Permaculture Design Certification Course

results.description:
Come join us on March 12th as we are planning to hold several sessions and challenges for kids of all ages and abilities.


This will include challenges designed for everyone from those new to programming to the more experienced young coder looking to work in Scratch and more advanced programming languages.

In addition, we will now be offering a program that includes Arduino for a select number of kids interested in micro-controllers.   


The kids from all groups will have the opportunity to showcase their work to the group and show what they have learned at the end of each session. We have a full fall agenda planned with CoderDojo Annapolis events to be held every other Saturday throughout the Winter and Spring. 

About Coder Dojo Annapolis


CoderDojo is a free, volunteer-led, community based programming club for young people between 7 and 17, where they can  learn how to code, develop websites, apps, programs, games and explore technology in an informal and creative environment. 


If I miss the first events, can we join later? Absolutely - anyone can join any anytime and they will be welcome and given the opportunity to get involved.


Do I need a laptop? No, but while we will have several laptops available to borrow, we do encourage kids who have access to a laptop to come with their own.

Does a parent need to be present? We encourage all parents to be involved and be present at all sessions. For children 12 years and under, a parent MUST stay in the room at all times. The parent may choose to participate in the session or not. For children 13 and above, the parent can choose to leave but it should be understood that we are in no way liable or responsible for your child. (see Legalese below)

Who are the mentors? Our mentors are adults working in various tech fields, educators and university students. We have a number of mentors and volunteers who have stepped up, but more are always needed and welcome (older kids are welcome to join and help as well - great on a resume!)

We look forward to seeing many of you. If you have any questions, please contact David Blackburn at[masked] or Dave Gilinson at [masked]

IMPORTANT NOTICE - By RSVPing for CoderDojo Annapolis on Meetup.com, you are consenting to participate in the CoderDojo workshop(s) on this basis.

LEGALESE VERSION (borrowed and adapted from other CoderDojos):

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily in their individual capacity. The host venue bears no formal relationship, responsibility or liability whatsoever in connection with the CoderDojo organizers or mentors and is offering its facilities to the CoderDojo Annapolis on a discretionary and good faith basis.

• All CoderDojo mentors are offering their services voluntarily and on a good faith, not-for profit, basis. Neither the CoderDojo mentors nor the host venue bear any responsibly or liability whatsoever or howsowever arising, for any loss or damage, whether direct or indirect, arising from any advice or instruction, or lack of advice or instruction, offered by any CoderDojo mentor.

• We are participating in this workshop on a fully voluntary basis and do so at our own risk. We are free to follow or not to follow the CoderDojo mentors’ advice as we decide. Neither the host venue nor the CoderDojo mentors bear any responsibly for any damage that may be caused as a result of their instruction or lack of instruction.

For example, if our laptop crashes or is damaged due to the downloading of any particular software suggested by a CoderDojo mentor, then we, and only we, bear full responsibility for any such damage and we hereby hold harmless and indemnify the host venue and the CoderDojo mentors and organizers for and against any claim for damages howsoever arising.

PHOTOGRAPHY: I understand that CoderDojo volunteers and news agencies may from time to time take photos or video of the CoderDojo sessions to be published for editorial or promotional purposes. If I do not want my child photographed, I understand that I need to make this known to the organizers at the beginning of the session. They will try to ensure that I am notified before any photography or videotaping for publication begins so I may remove my child during that time.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR PARTICIPANTS: Each child must be accompanied by an adult who signs in for him / her and is responsible for him / her during the session; this adult must stay for the entire session, no exceptions are permitted.

results.description:
Welcome to Warrior Meditation! These meditation sessions are secular and available to anyone wishing to meditate. All experience levels are welcome. During this session, I'll be offering 4 rounds of 10 to 15 minutes of Shamatha Meditation (also known as Calm Abiding, or Mindfulness meditation). If you are new to meditation and you would like to discuss the technique one on one, please send me a message, and we can schedule time before meditation to go over the technique. After the meditation session we discuss the meditation experience, and also take in select readings from a variety of meditation masters. The focus on most of our reading sessions is about using what we learn in meditation in every day life situations. 

Cheers!

Terri

results.description:
Greetings Everyone!

For those who've asked us to provide "Introduction to Buddhism" Meetups, we've put together this meetup which will follow our Saturday Warrior Mediation. We'll share a pot luck lunch starting at 12:00 and then go right into this meetup. This meetup involves listening to the audio version of Dzogchen Ponlop Rinpoche's book "Rebel Buddha" and then holding a discussion about the material afterwards. This book is a great entry point for westerners who are looking to understand the Buddhist path. It is very pithy, and adapted to our cultural understanding. Here is a brief description from Rinpoche about the contents of this book:

"There’s a rebel within you. It’s the part of you that already knows how to break free of fear and unhappiness. This rebel is the voice of your own awakened mind. It’s your rebel buddha—the sharp, clear intelligence that resists the status quo. It wakes you up from the sleepy acceptance of your day-to-day reality and shows you the power of your enlightened nature. It’s the vibrant, insightful energy that compels you to seek the truth."

We'll be playing the book from its audio version. But I also have 4 copies I can share with folks if you'd like a hardcopy for these sessions.

I look forward to seeing you!
Regards
Terri
results.name: Study Group: Rebel Buddha

I.ve been missing SoulCollage and many of you have missed it,too. So, come, create a few cards, leave your worries behind, let your creativity out Give yourself the gift of SoulCollage,

Please join us for an on going SoulCollage workshop. There is no beginning nor end. All supplies are provided. All you need to do is allow your creativity to come out and play. It's cutting and pasting with just a touch of introspection. As the tv ad once said, "try it, you'll like it"! I encourage you to bring your friend, mother or anyone who wants a couple of hours of fun, introspection and creativity. It will begin at 1 PM and end around 4 And of course, I'll spoil you with somthing yummy to eat and drink. PS If you are allergic to or do not like a not too big, friendly dog, please skip this event. Looking forward to another amazing group. Lynn

results.description:
Join the Jaycees as we crawl from bar to bar around Annapolis. Proceeds from participation in the crawl will all be donated to help Homeless Students in Anne Arundel County who desperately need our support!


UPDATE:

We will be starting our crawl at McGarvey's downtown at 2 pm then will be moving to Galway Bay, Harry Browne's Upstairs Bar, Ram's Head (by 5 pm), and then continuing the party at our favorite spot, Stan & Joe's!

In order to participate in the crawl, we will be collecting donations to benefit the Homeless Students of Anne Arundel County ($20 per person). It's going to a really great cause, and because of you a homeless student in our county will have access to athletic equipment, music instruments, and even a prom dress. Money will also be donated to help the general welfare of these students, whether that means providing money for a hotel room or for clothes.


There will also be some fun/silly bar challenges and a St. Patrick's Day theme, so come dressed in your best Irish attire! May the luck of the Irish be with you!
results.name: Bar Crawl to benefit Homeless Students of Anne Arundel County

results.description:
If you need another excuse to drink beer in Eastport, the annual Green Beer Races is a good reason to go. It's outdoor fun with a party crowd that includes a decent spread of food and drinks inside the Eastport Democratic Club building. Our SHR group attended the past two years and had a good time. The Irish dancers and live music were cool, and the beer racing teams took to the field with gusto!

This is how Eye on Annapolis described last year's event:

The Annual Green Beer Races will be taking place at the Eastport Democratic Club from the Crack of Noon (or thereabouts) to 9pm. The club, will host 4-person (2 men, 2 women), Bar/Restaurant, Relay, and Children’s (Kool-Aid) races in addition to the annual Men’s and Women’s Keg Toss.

The Event will feature a series of team relay races in which contestants will carry Green Beer on trays while completing a team course as fast as possible. The competition works like the NCAA Bracket and will consist of teams facing off in a single elimination setting, with the winning team of each race moving to the next round. Entertainment will be provided by the Eastport Oyster Boys and the Teelin School of Irish Dance.  Oh, and there will be green beer–in the tradition of Eastport…plenty of it!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Jake's neon white hair
results.name: Eastport Green Beer Races

results.description:
Greetings.

Ah March.  Taxes.  Spring teases.  Madness (with or without basketball).  Come on out and join a good group in learning a great tool or fine tuning the one you already have.


Breath is a powerful way to get out of your head for a bit and reconnect with your body.  It can be used to relax, un-clench, de-stress or just find out how to breathe more efficiently.  Being in group is a great way to try it out and see what you think.   No experience needed.  If there is no specific topic mentioned we can freestyle it or create a theme on the day of the breathe.


We will get together for an afternoon of:

1. Introductions


2. How are things?  Breath instruction.


3. Breath experience

4. Discussion after the experience

Date:  March 12, 2016


Time: 230pm - 430pm

Location: just South of Towson University

(exact directions will be sent to members coming to the meetup)

No prior experience is needed, just bring a willingness to try and an open mind.

Please arrive just before 230pm so that we can start on time and end right at 430pm.

You may want to bring a pillow with you.  Nothing special to wear, just something comfortable.


The $20.00 fee is payable at the door with cash or check.

Look forward to seeing you there!  Questions?  Shoot me a note.


Peace

David
results.name: Men's Breathe March 12  2016

results.description:
If you would like to be a 7-10 minute speaker talking about a travel experience, please let me know what place you would like to speak about. We are looking for 3 people to speak at this meeting. This could become a regular activity at our monthly meetings if the group likes the idea.

Casey and I are prepared to talk with you about a new cruise line called Fathom that will sail exclusively to the Dominican Republic for impact travel (helping the citizens of northern Dominican Republic) and to Cuba for cultural exchange travel.

At our last meeting each attendee (21 of us) talked about where they have traveled in the past and where they would like to travel in the future. We also agreed to meet monthly. If you would like suggest a get together for a special social activities such as a meal or happy hour where meetup group members can get to know each other and find possible travel partners. Just message either Casey Coven or Claire Hodgkin,.   We will be posting the Embassy Tour information in the next week or two.

Finally, we have a 2 question survey we would like you to answer:


1) Given a choice, would you rather cruise to the southeastern Caribbean (Barbados, St Lucia, Antigua, etc) or to the Panama Canal (through the first 2 sets of locks east to west and back w/stops in Aruba, Cartagena, Costa Rica)?

2) Given a choice would you rather spend 7 days traveling to London and Paris or 7 days traveling to Ireland?
